bibl.title: Letter from William A. Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, February 15, 1950

div1.p: Wood thanks Hench for his letter about the yellow fever survivors. He notes that it will be useful for a project to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Reed's work.

div1.head: Letter from William A. Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, February 15, 1950
div1.opener:
ADDRESS OFFICIAL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE SECRETARY OF STATE
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
DEPARTMENT OF STATE
WASHINGTON
February 15, 1950
Y F
In reply refer to
PL
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
May I express my appreciation of the time and
attention it is evident you gave to the letter to
me about the yellow fever survivors. It is a most
interesting report and contains all the information
needed to undertake a project in commemoration of
Walter Reed's invaluable contribution to medicine
on the 50th anniversary of the work.

I am bringing your letter to the immediate
attention of the “We, the People” staff and am
prepared to approach others should anything stand
in the way of this group's proceeding with a broad-
cast highlight. I will inform you of developments
since it is obvious that the yellow fever experiment
story and the men who took part are close to your
heart.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, William A. Wood
Acting Chief
Radio, Television & Visual Media Branch
Division of Public Liaison Philip S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
102-110 Second Avenue Southwest
Rochester, Minnesota
